titleInfo.title: Prison Personnel and Workplace Social Capital

name.namePart: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
College of Criminology and Criminal Justice

mods:mods.abstract: Scholarship suggests that correctional personnel play an integral role in the daily life of incarcerated persons (IPs). They influence life in prison for IPs and social order. At the same time, they may be affected by prison conditions. Indeed, prison work has been shown to be among the most challenging types of occupations and to contribute to higher levels of stress, suicide, and other adverse outcomes. Yet, much remains unknown about the factors that enable personnel to successfully navigate these conditions and, in turn, experience less stress and have greater job satisfaction and positive views about their work environment, including IPs. This dissertation examines workplace social capital (WSC) and its effects on prison personnel. The broader goal is to contribute to research and scholarship on the factors that influence prison personnel experiences and the impacts of correctional work on them, and, in turn, the potential role that these experiences and impacts may have on IP experiences and correctional systems. More specifically, it examines WSC among prison personnel, including who has WSC and its potential effects on personnel stress and views about their work, IPs, and the prison system. To this end, the dissertation draws on quantitative data from a study, "The Impacts of Restrictive Housing on Inmate Behavior, Mental Health, Recidivism, and Prison Systems and Personnel," to address the following interrelated research questions. First, what is the prevalence of WSC among prison personnel and, second, what factors are associated with WSC? Chapter 4 of the dissertation explores both of these questions by examining the prevalence and predictors of WSC. Third, does WSC influence the employment experiences and perceptions of individuals who are employed within the corrections system? Chapter 5 of the dissertation examines the effects of WSC on prison personnel's perceptions of IPs, perceived job stress and satisfaction, and perceptions of the correctional system. Fourth, does WSC influence the experiences and perceptions of individuals who are employed within restrictive housing (RH)? Chapter 6 examines whether working within RH amplifies the effect of WSC on prison personnel perceptions and experiences. This dissertation presents findings from the analyses and then discusses their implications for theory, research, and policy.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Criminology and Criminal Justice in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Correctional Officers, Prison, Prison Work, Workplace Social Capital
Daniel P. Mears, Professor Directing Dissertation; Melissa Radey, University Representative; Carter Hay, Committee Member; Joseph A. Schwartz, Committee Member.

etd:degree.etd:name: Doctor of Philosophy
etd:degree.etd:discipline: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
